Dickie, Mrs. Elsie
Togo.

To Sask. - November, 1902.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Elsie Dickie.
2. Your address: Togo, Sask.
3. Date: [Handwritten date not legible]
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or if you may use "I was in my teens", etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?

Below we have listed the reasons why we came to Western Canada:

- We wanted to be closer to family and friends.
- We needed land to farm and provide for our family.
- We thought the opportunity for homesteading was available.

And we have never regretted our decision.

Although we have lots of work to do,
Dickie, Mrs. Elsie
Togo.

To Sask. - November, 1902.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Elsie Dickie.
2. Your address: Togo.
3. Date: [Blank]
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): New York, Canada.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Charles Ross, farmer.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): January 1908.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - At Bramble, Idaho, came in 1889.
   - To Canada in 1899.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to say "I was in my teens", etc.). I was 24 years old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - We wanted a better life.
   - We needed land to homestead.
   - We had never neglected farming.

In the winter of 1891, my husband and I traveled through Idaho and into the woods looking for work. We thought the work would be suitable for homesteading. And we have never regretted our decision.

All of us have lots of hopes and dreams.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought I was quite a venture.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

You traveled with my twin brother.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

One team of horses & one team of oxen. It was slow traveling but we never regretted it.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

On the last lap of our journey we traveled 12 miles in a blizzard which was very tiring.

The next morning we found a nice people off the stepping place. They had no encounter with Indians.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

In the summer of 1908 my husband & brother came a field on the land & built a small cabin close to the farm where we now live.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have not lived any place but near of Sage.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Farming
12. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Eastern Canada?

They thought it was quite a good idea.

If so, how did they react? Our minds made up.

There was nothing more to be said.

13. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Yes, traveled with my two brothers.

14. What mode of transportation did you use?

One form of horse, a mule or oxen. If we used slow traveling, but we never regretted it.

15. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement.)

On the last part of our journey we traveled 12 miles on a plow road, which was very bumpy.

We kept armed every kind of weapon, ready for the wilderness places. We had no encounters with Indians.

16. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

In the summer of 1908, my husband & brother came a field on the land; built a small cabin about 10 feet from where we now live.

17. Where did you settle or take up land?

Right where we now live!

18. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have not lived any place but here at Sage.

19. How did you earn a living before coming to Eastern Canada? How after you came?

Farming
As we came through the rain from a past
officer's home and the smile or reserve mail
offered, we did not know how to respond to its offer.

God had two brothers who immediately
came on the same occasion as we did.
The other one came shortly after.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
memory which you would like to recount?

As I was the only person in the camp (at least) some months
ago, I was often called upon to perform various tasks for
the men working on the farm. I remember one time when
I had to bake bread for the men. I remember how hard
it was to get the dough right and how long it took me
to knead it. It was a difficult task, but I enjoyed it.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For instance, attending church,
visiting relatives, etc.) How often? How far?

There was no time to travel anywhere.
We were busy making a living in the harsh conditions of
the bush. In those years, people rarely left their homes.
Services of church were held in various
locations throughout the year. The minister would come
in the afternoon, the women would cook dinner
for him while he preached. After dinner, they would
walk back to their homes about an hour's
distance away. They worked hard and lived simply.

25. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For instance, attending church,
visiting relatives, etc.) How often? How far?

There was no time to travel anywhere.
We were busy making a living in the harsh conditions of
the bush. In those years, people rarely left their homes.
Services of church were held in various
locations throughout the year. The minister would come
in the afternoon, the women would cook dinner
for him while he preached. After dinner, they would
walk back to their homes about an hour's
distance away. They worked hard and lived simply.
As you know, I wrote you a letter from a past
office, but did not write again or receive mail
from you often, so every one was glad to see me.

I had two brothers who lived near me,
one on the same road as we did
the other one mile distant.

And when the only person in the house (some months
ago) opened the door of dinner and a delicious
smell came through the house, I knew it was time
to have him back at home. We enjoyed our dinner
very much. On Christmas morning in 1907 when
Christmas was still young, we thought of having
Christmas dinner. But we did not want to be late
for dinner and the weather was very cold.

There was no time to travel anywhere
and as the minister had another place to attend
in the afternoon, the dinner was cancelled.

On Friday morning from Walsh Road,
we walked until we were about an hour
away working while spread out far
but they would never wander away too far.
25. Then was the first car used in the community?

1914

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes?

The Fordland was Ford car only in 1915.

27. Where was your trading centre? How far from home?

Fogo, which is 34 1/2 miles from home.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new terms appear-

ing, better means of transportation, etc.)

You were still trade at Fogo. At times we

found at Carberry, Winnipeg.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

When we had to go sixty miles for food, we did

shop very often. Now once a week.

30. Did anyone (husband) disappear in your district? First start going to town regularly.

On Saturdays.

31. Did you have a general store? About how big?

There were several cars. About 1915

If you had a car, you bought them away.

32. Then did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

In 1917

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying

permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you

make this decision?

For me came to Bath with the sole purpose

Of working a farm or playing pool.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

1914

26. If you owned a car before 1931, then did you buy it? What make?

Yes

27. How far from town was your home?

34 1/2 miles

28. Did you continue to take them? (Indicate any changes due to new terms appear-

ing, better means of transportation, etc.)

Yes

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

When we had to go to town, we went once a week.

30. Did you have a car in your family? If so, how many?

Yes

31. How many cars did you own?

About 1917

32. What kind of car did you own?

Ford

33. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

In 1917

34. When did you come to Saskatchewan the first time? Was it with the idea of staying

permanent? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? Then did you

make this decision?

For our came to Saskatchewan for the sole purpose

of making a home or staying put.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1943? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, two. But some homesteaders came here.

35. If so, what people moved away? Why did they move?

They were just after school and did not want to play in the first place.

No, we were not so hard hit with the drought on South Beach.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I have been a homemaker for 47 years.

I was president for four years when the club fair organized in 1931.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My husband was the first to have an automobile.

And buying my own car. He probably have a new combine along before. But was 1943.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, etc.) Give origin and meaning of the name.

One of the earliest to name a farm in Portland (Albion), the railway called it a "The Village Lodge," named after Carnival Log of Japan.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? If so, why?

Yes, they did. But some homesteaded here first.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? If so, why?

No, we were not so hard hit with the drought on South Beach.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I have been a homemaker for 47 years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in having an automobile, combine them together whenever possible.

The first automobile was purchased by Mr. Johnson in 1928.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption. Any changes in name since the first name was given.

One of the earliest known names was "Poveshell," the railroad station.

The village of Largo, named after Carnival.

Largo Bay Station.
